article.writingAngle: Temperature limits and material selection - helping readers choose the right PVC type based on temperature requirements

company.name: Bastone
company.coreBusiness: Manufacturing of plasticizers and PVC resin for the plastics industry. Bastone produces essential chemical additives and base materials used in polymer applications, serving as a key supplier of compounds for PVC and flexible plastic manufacturing.
company.valueProposition: As a specialized manufacturer of plasticizers and PVC resin in China, Bastone provides essential raw materials for the plastics industry with a focus on quality chemical compounds for diverse polymer applications.

goals.primary: Understand what plasticizers and PVC resin are
secondary: Understand how these materials are used

alreadyKnows: Plastics are everywhere in daily life
Some awareness that plastics are manufactured from raw materials
Basic understanding of flexible vs rigid plastics
General awareness of PVC as a type of plastic

writingApproach.style: Conversational; use analogies and real-world examples
writingApproach.complexity: Simple sentences; define all jargon; avoid acronyms or explain them immediately
writingApproach.structure: Start with 'why it matters'; build concepts step-by-step
writingApproach.wordChoice: Everyday language; assume no prior knowledge

do: Use everyday analogies: 'Think of plasticizers like adding oil to bread doughâ€”it makes the material more flexible...'
Connect to familiar products: 'The flexible garden hose, the vinyl flooring in kitchens...'
Use second person ('you') to create connection: 'You've probably used products containing plasticizers today without realizing it.'
Make chemistry accessible: 'The chemistry might sound complex, but the concepts are actually quite intuitive.'
Maintain slow and methodical pacing. One concept at a time.
Adopt chemistry teacher tone making industrial concepts relatable
dont: Assume knowledge of chemistry or polymer science

userContext.situation: The reader needs to select or specify PVC materials for an application where temperature exposure is a concern. They may be evaluating product specifications, comparing supplier options, or troubleshooting a temperature-related failure.
userContext.currentState: Confused about temperature ratings on PVC datasheets; uncertain whether standard PVC will work for their temperature conditions; unclear about the difference between continuous and intermittent temperature limits.
userContext.desiredState: Confident understanding of PVC temperature capabilities; able to match PVC type to temperature requirements; knows what questions to ask suppliers about temperature performance.

searchIntent.coreQuestion: What temperatures can PVC withstand, and how do I choose the right type for my temperature conditions?
implicitQuestions: What's the difference between rigid PVC and flexible PVC temperature ratings?
Can PVC handle hot water? How hot?
What happens to PVC when it gets too hot or too cold?
Are there high-temperature PVC formulations available?
How do plasticizers affect temperature performance?
searchIntent.successCriteria: After reading, the reader can identify the standard temperature range for common PVC types, understand the factors that affect temperature limits (formulation, plasticizers), and make an informed initial material selection based on their application's temperature requirements.

goldenInsights.insight: At 140F, PVC retains only 20% of its room-temperature pressure capacity - dramatic reduction most readers do not expect
Plastics expand 4-5x more than metal pipes - many installations fail because designers do not account for this
23% of CPVC system failures are caused by thermal expansion, not the material itself
Rigid PVC Tg is 80C but flexible PVC Tg can go as low as -42C - same base material, totally different behavior

coverage: Competitors lack beginner-friendly explanation of WHY temperature limits exist
Rigid vs flexible PVC temperature differences not addressed by competitors
Cold temperature behavior largely ignored by competitors
No real-world failure examples in competitor content

research.coreThesis: Understanding the why behind PVC temperature limits (glass transition temperature) helps you choose the right material and avoid the most common installation mistakes

emphasize: Glass transition temperature concept - key differentiator, explain with analogy
De-rating table - strong data, provide complete table
CPVC comparison - clear decision point for readers
Thermal expansion - practical installation concern with specific data
Plasticizer effects - connects to company business (Bastone makes plasticizers)

hookUsed.content: At 140F, PVC pipe retains only 20% of its room-temperature pressure capacity

opinionsIncluded: What Temperature Can PVC Withstand: The 140F limit is conservative for a reason - approach it and pressure capacity drops dramatically
Why Does PVC Have Temperature Limits: Understanding Tg is more valuable than memorizing limits
How Do Plasticizers Change PVC Temperature Behavior: Plasticizer selection is the hidden lever for temperature performance
What Happens When PVC Gets Too Hot or Too Cold: Cold weather fears are overblown; heat is the real concern
When Should You Use CPVC Instead of PVC: CPVC is right above 120F, but installation matters more than material choice
How to Install PVC Properly: 23% of failures come from ignoring thermal expansion - the material is not the problem
How to Choose the Right PVC Type: Start with max expected temperature, add safety margin, then choose material
